docs.lead_paragraph: A romantic drama about a Brooklyn girl who finds fulfillment in the boxing ring, a first-time director's story of estranged siblings in a small town and a documentary about South Africa's struggle for justice won top honors at the 16th annual Sundance Film Festival tonight. The festival, the premier event in the independent film world, concludes its 10-day run on Sunday in Park City, Utah, its final day dedicated to encore screenings of tonight's award winners. This year's assortment of feature films, documentaries and short films was widely viewed as among the richest to appear in recent years at the festival, which has been the launching pad for such independent hits as ''sex, lies and videotape,'' ''Shine'' and ''The Blair Witch Project.''

headline.main: Sundance Jury Picks the Best of Rich Crop of Independent Films

docs.lead_paragraph: Why, there's Oscar Wilde again, looking ever so sleek. The aesthete par excellence, who has been represented in melancholy terms of late, shows up fully restored to his flamboyant glory in Tom Stoppard's ''Invention of Love,'' which is receiving its American premiere here, insisting that he has no regrets after all. ''Better a fallen rocket,'' he declares in a voice that does indeed soar like a Roman candle, ''than never a burst of light.'' The trajectory of that particular rocket's fall has been traced solemnly and repeatedly in recent years, in works like David Hare's ''Judas Kiss'' and Moises Kaufman's ''Gross Indecency.'' Mr. Stoppard, however, is using the conflagration that was Oscar Wilde to cast a glow on another literary figure who pursued his life far more in the shadows: the poet and classics scholar A. E. Housman.
docs.abstract: Ben Brantley reviews American premiere of Tom Stoppard play, The Invention of Love, directed by Carey Perloff and presented by American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco; James Cromwell stars; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Golden Globes As Crystal Balls Producers, studio executives and agents agree that in a town of often odd events, the Golden Globes ceremony ranks as one of the oddest. The annual award show, which was broadcast on NBC on Sunday, is often seen as a harbinger of the Academy Awards. But the track record of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which gives the awards, is mixed.
docs.abstract: At the Movies column comments on Golden Globe awards, sometimes considered harbinger of Oscars; DreamWorks re-releases American Beauty following awards; John Pogue (Yale) and Rob Cohen (Harvard) use their knowledge of Ivy League elite to create thriller, The Skulls, about overachieving, poor New Haven townie who joins elitist secret society; Wes Craven comments on completion of his Scream trilogy of horror films; photos (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Theater ''THE AFRICAN DRUM.'' As part of the celebration of African-American history month, the Shadow Box Theater presents a people-and-puppet musical of adventure and folk tales set to African music. At Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. Tomorrow at 11 a.m. Tickets $8. Reservations: (212) 864-5400. ''CHARLOTTE'S WEB.'' Theaterworks/USA presents the classic tale by E. B. White of Wilbur the pig and Charlotte the spider, and their journey of bravery, love and discovery of the true meaning of friendship. In this hourlong production, with book by Joseph Robinette, Charlotte assures her friend Wilbur that she will save him from the slaughterhouse. Auditorium at Equitable, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 52nd Street, tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 p.m. Through Feb. 6. Tickets $19. Reservations: (212) 627-7373.

docs.lead_paragraph: Flare-Up At 'Fever' Actors Equity, the union of actors and stage managers, was investigating an increasingly tense backstage scene at ''Saturday Night Fever'' this week, a situation apparently triggered by a dismissal of the stage manager. That move has sparked bad blood between some in the cast and management, as well as the resignation of three assistant stage managers on Wednesday.
docs.abstract: On Stage and Off column; Actors Equity investigates tense backstage scene at Saturday Night Fever, situation apparently triggered by dismissal of stage manager Perry Cline after he signed cast letter to producer Robert Stigwood; letter objected to quality of souvenir programs; Donald Margulies comedy Dinner With Friends has become quiet Off-Broadway hit at Variety Arts Theater; Edward Hibbert to play role of grandmother in The Green Bird, Carlo Gozzi's 18th-century Italian fable; Illeana Douglas to star in The Moment When, James Lapine's new play, at Playwrights Horizons; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vivien Leigh lights a cigarette. Sigmund Freud lights a cigar. That's what they should be doing, isn't it? Miss Leigh is a glamorous movie star of a bygone era, and everyone knows about Dr. Freud and cigars. Still, when you consider that both are ill with only a short time to live, smoking is probably the last thing they should be doing.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''It's very difficult to live in war,'' says Sanel, who is 12. ''You just wait for the moment you will die.'' In the last 10 years two million children have been killed in increasingly brutal civil wars and ethnic or religious conflict. For nearly half of that decade Alan and Susan Raymond, American television-documentary makers who are nothing if not tenacious, have been talking to children in four of the world's most tragic recent battlegrounds.
docs.abstract: Children at War, documentary by Alan and Susan Raymond that will be shown on HBO, is result of five years they spent talking to children in four of world's most tragic recent battlegrounds: Bosnian city of Mostar, Rwanda, segregated communities of Northern Ireland and troubled neighborhoods where Palestinians and Israelis wreak vengeance on one another; film is not so much about children as by them; photos (L)

headline.main: When War Steals a Parent, or a Childhood; Filmmakers Explore How Young Victims Fared in Four of the World's Battlegrounds
